summary: Arthur Schlesinger is mentioned in the context of the Bay of Pigs invasion and anti-Castro activities. He is referenced in a memorandum evaluating Edward J. Hamilton's manuscript on the Bay of Pigs invasion, which criticizes figures in the Kennedy Administration. He is also mentioned in documents related to Richard Goodwin's involvement in anti-Castro activities, including the Cuba Task Force and Operation Mongoose. Additionally, he appears in memoranda and minutes related to covert actions and discussions concerning Cuba and the Dominican Republic, including potential assassination plots and sabotage operations.
significance: Arthur Schlesinger's significance in the JFK context lies in his association with the Kennedy administration and his indirect involvement in discussions and activities related to anti-Castro efforts, including the Bay of Pigs invasion and potential assassination plots. The documents suggest he was part of the broader policy and decision-making environment concerning Cuba during the Kennedy era.
